title: The Ordinaryâ€™s New Serum Ended My Botox Obsession â€” & Itâ€™s Cheaper
description: .disclaimer{width:90%;margin-bottom:1rem}.disclaimer__lines{width:100%;margin:0 auto;border-bottom:1px solid #999;padding:0;max-width:150px}.disclaimer__copy{width:100%;max-width:355px;font-family:Brown Regular,sans-serif;font-size:.9rem;font-weight:300;line-height:1.3em;color:#333;padding:0 0 .4rem;margin:1rem auto;text-align:center} All linked products are independently selected by our editors. If you purchase any of these products, we may earn a commission. I have a confession to make. While I extol the virtues of wearing SPF on a daily basis (yes, even in the winter), I havenâ€™t always been so diligent about protecting my skin from the sun. These days, â€œcleanse, moisturize, sunscreenâ€ is my skincare mantra but Iâ€™m beginning to notice the effects of all those years I spent (mostly inadvertently) collecting rays.Â  Besides a few broken capillaries around my nose, most of my sun damage â€” exacerbated by a nasty case of accidental forehead sunburn in a surprisingly hot Cyprus last October â€” presents as fine lines. Donâ€™t get me wrong. Skin texture is entirely normal and lines and wrinkles are a usual part of aging. But if some of that texture is at least partly self-inflicted, is there a way to reverse it? Youâ€™re probably shouting â€œBotox!â€ at your screen, and while the skin-smoothing injectable has its merits (R29 is a totally judgement-free zone), Iâ€™m taking a break following a recent bad experience where my brows and eyelids drooped significantly. Whatâ€™s more, my forehead was almost too smooth. I like to see some skin texture â€” thatâ€™s the key to natural-looking tweakments â€” and so I broke up with the stuff.Â  It seems Iâ€™m not the only one. Lots of my beauty editor peers are giving up expensive line-smoothing injections, opting instead for deeply hydrating skincare to plump their skin sans needles. Most notably, serums and moisturizers with one key ingredient: growth factors or GF.Â Â  What is GF â€” or growth factors â€” and what are the skincare benefits? Growth factors are a type of peptide, or protein, known to stimulate skin cell growth over time. They are often used to heal wounds but skincare brands have since found another use for them, namely boosting collagen and elastin â€” two things that are found naturally in our skin, giving it structure and suppleness. Collagen and elastin deplete as we age but sun exposure and other environmental aggressors like pollution can speed up the process, resulting in fine lines and skin laxity.Â  Growth factors are a relatively new innovation in the skincare world, so products that enlist them are typically eye-wateringly expensive. But you can always count on The Ordinary to democratize a buzzy ingredient. This week it launched GF 15% Solution, $15.50, a serum boasting three types of plant-based growth factors. The Ordinary GF 15% Solution, $15.50 What are epidermal growth factors? First up, EGF or epidermal growth factors. In a previous Refinery29 article, aesthetics practitioner Dr. Ioannis Liakas told us that epidermal growth factors promote cell growth on the epidermis, or outer layer of the skin, resulting in faster healing and better repair. â€œThey are known to be gentler on the skin than retinols as they do not have the same flaking effects,â€ said Dr. Liakas. He added, â€œ[Epidermal growth factors] can be used in the morning and evening, but [using them] in the evening will help to achieve optimal effects because this is when cellular turnover is at its highest healing peak.â€Â  Besides epidermal growth factors, The Ordinaryâ€™s serum also features IGF or insulin-like growth factors, which research shows regenerate and repair damaged cells. Lastly, the serum boasts TGF or transforming growth factors. Studies suggest these can stimulate collagen production and reduce inflammation or redness.Â  Is The Ordinaryâ€™s GF 15% Solution any good? With science out of the way, this serum is The Ordinaryâ€™s first foray into growth factors. Intrigued, I incorporated it into my skincare routine as soon as I received it in November, layering it underneath a simple moisturizer after cleansing in the evening, and the same in the morning â€” always following with sunscreen.Â  I have to get one gripe out of the way first: The texture is watery â€” more akin to a toner than any serum Iâ€™m used to â€” but that means it absorbs quickly and without leaving behind any tackiness. As such, I wouldnâ€™t recommend putting the dropper to your face Ã  la TikTokâ€™s skincare enthusiasts; the serum will just roll off. Instead, I like to squeeze a pipette-full into the palm of my hand and pat it gently into my skin. I used the serum every day for over a month and I noticed a difference in my skin texture almost immediately. It appeared smoother and more taut, as though Iâ€™d applied a blurring makeup primer. I spotted the biggest change in the fine lines across my forehead after three weeks, especially when wearing makeup; it was like theyâ€™d been ironed out. Impressive. Donâ€™t just take my word for it, though. Refinery29 senior writer Karina Hoshikawa is equally enamored with the product: â€œGrowth factors in skincare have been quietly trending for quite some time now, and Iâ€™ll admit that they sounded a bit too good to be true â€” also, very expensive,â€ she says. â€œBut because I will happily try anything The Ordinary releases, I eagerly began testing its new GF 15% Solution as soon as I got an early bottle during the brandâ€™s activation at Miamiâ€™s Art Basel in early December.â€ Karina continues: â€œThanks to good genes and regular sunscreen use, I still get asked for ID every time I buy wine (Iâ€™m 31), but I definitely want to keep my skin looking as healthy as possible for as long as possible. I started getting Botox this year, and have to say that Iâ€™m a novice when it comes to growth factors in my routine. That said, I was excited to incorporate GF 15% Solution as irregular tone and texture are my two primary skincare concerns. Right off the bat, I loved the lightweight texture of the serum; my skin readily drank it up. It felt super gentle on my skin and played well with my morning and nighttime routine.â€ Within two weeks of twice-daily use, Karina felt like her chronically dehydrated skin looked and felt plumper and more even overall. â€œI donâ€™t really have wrinkles or fine lines but the rough texture I have on my forehead and cheeks was visibly diminished â€” almost as if theyâ€™d been filled in ever so slightly,â€ she says. â€œI was honestly blown away by the early results and canâ€™t wait to see what my skin looks like after finishing my first bottle.â€ The firming and lifting effects reported in the brandâ€™s clinical trials remain to be seen, adds Karina. â€œBut if I continue to see improvement in my overall skin health and appearance, Iâ€™ll be extremely satisfied with the results.â€Â  If youâ€™re sold, there are a couple more things you should know. While this didnâ€™t irritate mine or Karinaâ€™s skin in any way, The Ordinary advises against using it in the same skincare routine as vitamin C and exfoliating acids like glycolic, lactic and salicylic acids. These potent ingredients are said to break down the growth factors, potentially rendering them ineffective. In other words, itâ€™s money down the drain.Â  When it comes to things like fine lines, prevention is infinitely better than cure. I really enjoyed using this serum but investing in a high factor, broad spectrum sunscreen that protects against UVA (rays responsible for premature aging and skin cancer) and UVB (which causes sunburn) is also key.Â  Lastly, Karina points out that growth factors tend to be synonymous with triple-digit prices. â€œThe Ordinaryâ€™s innovative formula retails for $15.50, so itâ€™s truly a game-changer in democratizing cutting-edge skincare for all,â€ she says â€” and I agree. Having recently tried a $148 skin-smoothing serum which promised similar results, I can firmly say that GF 15% Solution is just as effective (especially when teamed with sunscreen) â€” and a snip of the price, too. This story wasÂ originally published on Refinery29Â UK. Like what you see? How about some more R29 goodness, right here?R29 Staff Share Their All-Time Favorite SkincareA Derm Told Me To Make These Skincare Resolutions8 Skincare Trends Thatâ€™ll Be Everywhere In 2025
author: Jacqueline Kilikita

title: 16 Hair Color Trends Thatâ€™ll Take Over Salons This Year, According To Experts
description: If your New Yearâ€™s resolution is to be braver, let top hair colorists lead the way. This January and beyond, you can expect an abundance of both striking and totally wearable hair color trends to infiltrate salons.Â  From mocha mousse (which takes its cue from Pantoneâ€™s Color of the Year for 2025) to amber blonde (a more muted take on the bold copper tones that dominated previous months), thereâ€™s something for everyone â€” whether youâ€™re willing to put in the work to maintain your chosen hue or youâ€™re a shampoo-and-go kind of person. DashDividers_1_500x100 Microlights View this post on Instagram A post shared by Ayesha Marr (@ayeshamarr) This year, blonde hair trends are going to be more natural and lived in, reports Nina Brown, senior colorist at Neil Moodie Studio â€” and theyâ€™ll take inspiration from no-makeup makeup. â€œThis is achieved by a very subtle balayage technique [known as] babylights,â€ which are highlights on very thin strands of hair. â€œItâ€™s like no-color color,â€ says Brown, â€œand the tones are moving more towards honey and strawberry blonde vibes.â€ This color on Ayesha Marr by BLEACH London is beautiful.Â  Airy Lights View this post on Instagram A post shared by Amelia Swaby (@ameliaswaby) Imagined by celebrity colorists ZoÃ« Irwin and Nicola Clarke at John Frieda, airy lights are essentially teeny tiny blonde highlights that are dotted along both sides of the [hair part] and carefully laid over a darker tone for contrast, as seen on model Amelia Swaby. â€œThese micro lights are really super fine,â€ says Irwin, â€œand the deepness underneath is important.â€ This means that it doesnâ€™t look â€œmanufacturedâ€, says Clarke. â€œInstead, itâ€™s so natural that itâ€™s like [the highlights] are growing out of the scalp [as individual hair strands].â€ Depending on the shade of blonde, airy lights have many nuances, which leads us nicely onto the next trendâ€¦ Oat CendrÃ© View this post on Instagram A post shared by âœ§âœ§ ğ•½ğ–„ğ•°ğ•¹ğ•¹ğ•° ğ•¾ğ•¹ğ•ºğ–‚ âœ§âœ§ (@ryennesnow.hair) The French word â€œcendrÃ©â€ translates into English as â€œbonfire ashesâ€ â€” a mix of grey and black tones. Oat cendrÃ©, then, is essentially a mix of ash blonde and creamy, oat milky tones. Look to this shade by Ryenne Snow. â€œThis trend is all to do with the rise of the super natural, mid-blonde hue,â€ says Irwin, â€œand again, deeper tones lie underneath it.â€ Both Clarke and Irwin reference Taylor Swift and Jennifer Lawrence.Â  Taupe CendrÃ© View this post on Instagram A post shared by Sophia Karayiannis (@colourbyfie) The last hair color trend in the airy lights dynasty is taupe cendrÃ© â€” a dark blonde shade better suited to brunettes, like this color on digital creator Issy Sedgwick by Sophia Karayiannis. â€œThere has been a surge in mid or â€˜mousyâ€™ blonde,â€ says Irwin, â€œbut we prefer to call it taupe cendrÃ© [thanks to the] beige-y ash tones within this color.â€ When painting taupe airy lights onto darker hair, Clarke and Irwin never take the color all the way to the root. Stopping just short of the hair part lends a halo effect, says Clarke, as though thereâ€™s a ring light above your head.Â  Monobrown View this post on Instagram A post shared by âœ¨â›“ ğ”ğ”ğ”±ğ”±ğ”¶ğ” ğ”ğ”ğ”¯ğ” ğ”¢ğ”©ğ” â„Œğ”¢ğ”¯ğ”«ğ”ğ”«ğ”¡ğ”¢ğ”· â›“âœ¨ (@dreamhairbycelaa) Tom Smith, a hairstylist and trend forecaster, notes that in the latter half of 2024, many of us ditched the lighter tones and went brunette. Take smoky brunette and candlelit brunette, for example. â€œThere were lots of slightly different tones of deep brunette,â€ says Smith. â€œSome warmer, some more neutral and cooler, but the characteristic that they all share is that monochromatic finish.â€Â  Enter: monobrown, a one-dimensional brunette color in its â€œmost authenticâ€ form rather than with heaps of highlights or lowlights. â€œ[Monobrown is] very much a focus on healthy, glossy, monochromatic brunette,â€ says Smith. Look to this shade on a client of colorist and stylist Kattya Marcela Hernandez. Russet Red View this post on Instagram A post shared by âœ§âœ§ ğ•½ğ–„ğ•°ğ•¹ğ•¹ğ•° ğ•¾ğ•¹ğ•ºğ–‚ âœ§âœ§ (@ryennesnow.hair) Zoe Adams, international artist at Taylor Taylor London, says that while copper has long been a staple for autumn and winter, the salon demand has never been so high. â€œWeâ€™re seeing a full embrace of coppers, auburns and reds in the salon this season â€” and I see no sign of this trend slowing down into 2025.â€ Besides the diluted strawberry blonde hue as seen on Emma Stone at this yearâ€™s Golden Globes, Adams predicts that russet â€” a matte red erring on brown â€” will also take hold. â€œOur colorists are mixing softer, cooler tones into copper; you want to avoid anything veering towards orange.â€ Take inspiration from this shade on a client of Ryenne Snow.Â  Amber Blonde View this post on Instagram A post shared by Z (@_zfemi) If the above is a little too bold for your liking, consider a more muted shade like amber blonde, composed of similar auburn undertones. â€œWeâ€™ll continue to see warm blondes triumph over icy tones in 2025,â€ says Siobhan Haug, cofounder of Haug London Haus. â€œThis premium blonde blends honey, gold and a touch of auburn for a long-lasting, luminous tone,â€ says Haug. â€œItâ€™s perfect for anyone who wants to stay lighter for winter but needs a break from bleaching.â€ Haug suggests asking your colorist for a glossing toner over blonde highlights or an all-over blonde color. We love this shade on makeup artist and model Z.Â  Sunflower Blonde View this post on Instagram A post shared by Blonding Specialist Albuquerque (@hair_by_michellel) Smith recalls a time when gold and yellow tones were dismissed in salons. â€œThey were characteristic of a badly done blonde,â€ he says. â€œBut when you intentionally add golden tones into the hair, it has a very healthy, shiny, glowy and vibrant effect.â€Â  Sunflower blonde is as warm and intense as blonde can be before it tips into strawberry blonde or copper territory, says Smith, like this shade by blonde specialist Michelle. Vibro-RedsÂ  View this post on Instagram A post shared by âœ§âœ§ ğ•½ğ–„ğ•°ğ•¹ğ•¹ğ•° ğ•¾ğ•¹ğ•ºğ–‚ âœ§âœ§ (@ryennesnow.hair) â€œHyper pigments like these tend to have a bad rap,â€ says Irwin, not least because theyâ€™re difficult to get rid of if you happen to change your mind â€” especially if you want to go lighter. She continues, â€œActually, though, these reds can be super high fashion. Think Chappell Roan.â€ Clarke agrees: â€œVibro-red is almost â€˜80s-inspired with a mix of both copper and red.â€ Check out this shade on another client of hair artist Ryenne Snow.Â  Not So Boring Beige View this post on Instagram A post shared by Hairstylist âœ‚ï¸ (@hairbyalyssaa_) Far from bland, beige is shaping up to be a big trend in 2025, says Caroline Spencer, senior color director at House of Sassoon, adding, â€œIt offers a versatile and chic aesthetic that complements a range of skin tones.â€ Spencer points out that the trendâ€™s popularity has been reflected on multiple runways, most notably ChloÃ© AW24. Even Pantoneâ€™s Color of the Year â€” mocha mousse â€” takes a cue. â€œWhether itâ€™s a light champagne beige or a rich chocolate beige, the adaptability of beige tones allows you to customize the look to suit your personal style and base color,â€ says Spencer. We love this shade posted to Instagram by hairstylist Alyssa. Iced Chocolate View this post on Instagram A post shared by âœ§âœ§ ğ•½ğ–„ğ•°ğ•¹ğ•¹ğ•° ğ•¾ğ•¹ğ•ºğ–‚ âœ§âœ§ (@ryennesnow.hair) Beige doesnâ€™t always mean blonde. Spencer predicts weâ€™ll spot the tone mixed into rich chocolate shades to create a dusty brunette hue that suits all skin tones, much like this color on Ryenne Snow.Â  Milk Tea View this post on Instagram A post shared by Jonny salon (@jonny_salon) Following on from beige, searches for â€œmilk tea hair colorâ€ are on the rise this month, but your colorist will know it as dark ash blonde. This shade posted to Instagram by Jonny Salon illustrates the trend perfectly. Invest in a nourishing hair oil to enhance shine, like KÃ©rastase Elixir Ultime Lâ€™Huile Originale Hair Oil, $46. Bleach Dipping View this post on Instagram A post shared by Amira (@amira.locs) Rope twists, locs and twist-outs are the perfect styles for â€œbleach dippingâ€, say Irwin and Clarke, essentially dipped blonde ends. When you have bleached pieces like this, you can change the color really easily with a hair gloss or a temporary dye if you want to have fun and switch things up. Take inspo from Amira on Instagram. Heritage Blonde View this post on Instagram A post shared by Live True London Salons (@livetruelondon) â€œHeritage blonde is not just cool in tone but also in [attitude],â€ says Smith. â€œ[Compared to sunflower blonde], itâ€™s more understated and relaxed.â€ It consists of various neutral tones woven into the hair almost like tweed. â€œWhen it comes to heritage blonde, you canâ€™t see the story of where the color begins and ends,â€ says Smith. â€œItâ€™s much more fluid and blended, and it doesnâ€™t necessarily look like itâ€™s been freshly done â€” nor does it look like itâ€™s grown out. Itâ€™s definitely dirtier and more antique-looking,â€ hence the word â€œheritageâ€. Itâ€™s perfect for those who like low-maintenance hair color. Look to this shade by Sofia at Live True London Soho.Â  Terracopper View this post on Instagram A post shared by Michelle Thompson Hairstylist (@michellethompsonhair) Forget cowgirl copper. This year itâ€™s all about terracopper â€” terracotta meets copper â€” which is earthier and deeper than traditional copper shades weâ€™ve seen previously. â€œ[This] winter, itâ€™s getting even more vibrant,â€ says Smith. Take inspiration from this shade on Z, posted to Instagram by award-winning afro and textured hair specialist Michelle Thompson.Â â€œItâ€™s not dark or really dense,â€ adds Smith. â€œItâ€™s almost got a rose gold quality [to it] so itâ€™s a really interesting shade, and itâ€™s something that I think more people are going to be playing with.â€ It requires maintenance, though. Smith recommends investing in color-boosting conditioners or masks that contain red and copper tones to top up your hue. Try Moroccanoil Color Depositing Mask, $40.50, available in various shades. La Belle BohÃ¨me View this post on Instagram A post shared by PERTH BLONDE SPECIALIST SALON (@vivalablonde) The iconic photos of Kate Moss at Glastonbury festival serve as the ultimate inspiration behind the boho blonde hair color trend that flooded salons until recently. Fast-forward to 2025 and the shade has had a chic upgrade. â€œThe blonde is more muted and sophisticated; itâ€™s a fine lightness that only comes from the [hair part] section.â€ The hair is a lot deeper underneath, which makes it look luxe. â€œThis lightness is almost like a veil on top,â€ says Clarke, much like this shade by Viva La Blonde. This story wasÂ originally published on Refinery29Â UK. Like what you see? author: Jacqueline Kilikita

title: I Tried the Viral "Facelift" Concealer Hack From TikTok, and I Have Thoughts
description: I've been doing my makeup the same way for years - at least when it comes to concealer, bronzer, and blush - but even I started to second-guess my technique after every video (and I mean every video) on TikTok was telling me I was doing it the "outdated" way. According to the younger (read: cooler) crowd on the app, you're supposed to apply concealer only to the outer and inner corners of your eyes to give yourself an "instant facelift." But it doesn't stop there - you're also supposed to apply your contour and blush on your cheekbones (as opposed to the hollows of your cheeks for bronzer and the apples for blush). Due to the popularity of this new makeup hack on TikTok, I decided to give it a try to see if it truly does give your face that instantly lifted appearance, but I was skeptical. Here's how it went.
author: Jessica Harrington

title: 35 Small Tattoo Ideas That Are Simple and Cool
description: If you're nervous or stressed about how permanent tattoos are, trust us when we say: you're not alone. Removing a tattoo is no picnic, but committing to a single design among countless letters, symbols, and shapes often has us feeling like Maggie Carpenter in "Runaway Bride": terrified, confused, and doubtful. How are you supposed to choose something with so many options out there? If you're stuck on where to start, we've got you covered with the best small tattoo ideas. First, think about where you want your tattoo to be. Small finger tattoos, ankle tattoos, and wrist tattoos are most common - they're subtle but noticeable, and they make the perfect small tattoos. Whether you're seeking a spiritual symbol, interested in a colorful flower, or just testing the waters before committing to a full sleeve, these simple tattoo ideas showcase an array of abstract, typographic, and illustrative designs (without all those scary strings attached). If you don't want to go in alone, invite someone to get a tattoo with you. Small tattoo ideas for couples and best friends can turn your favorite inside jokes into a piece of art. No matter how you decide to do it, keep scrolling for some of our favorite cute tiny ink ideas. Related: 30 Tiny Friend Tattoos to Show Off How Close You Are
author: Sabrina Park
